question.title: Set Quarkus rest-client timeout for different rest clients
question.body:
I am trying to set two different timeout values for each one of my rest-clients

On my properties: quarkus.rest-client.client-api.read-timeout=75000 quarkus.rest-client.core-api.read-timeout=3600000

I am following the documentation: https://quarkus.io/guides/rest-client#quarkus-rest-client-config_quarkus-rest-client-read-timeout

On the docs I have the following for: quarkus.rest-client.read-timeout

A timeout in milliseconds that REST clients should wait for a response from the remote endpoint. Can be overwritten by client-specific settings.

For the PUT

@Path("/services")
@RegisterRestClient(configKey = "core-api")
public interface ServiceVersionApiRestClient {

@PUT
@Path("/{serviceId}/versions/{versionNumber}")
@Consumes(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)
@Produces(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)
Uni<ServiceVersionDto> updateServiceVersion(@PathParam("serviceId") String serviceId, @PathParam("versionNumber") Integer versionNumber, ServiceVersionUpdateDto service);

Usage:

serviceVersionApiRestClient.updateServiceVersion(serviceId, versionNumber, serviceVersionUpdateDto)
                .onFailure(this::isCauseInEnum)
                .transform(WorkflowVersionRestException::new)
                .map(workflowVersionApiRestMapper::toModel).await().atMost(Duration.ofMillis(TIMEOUT_LIMIT_MILLISECOND));

I have a timeout in 30 seconds that is the default value. How to solve this?

question_comments.body: Up to you - the lowest one will "win" in any case
Do you think .await().indefinitely() is good for this case or should I keep the timeout for the Uni too?
@geoand you absolutely right In the end it was the await().atMost(duration) method causing the timeout and not the Rest client
Each client interface having its own timeouts should work just fine, do you have an example where it doesn't work that I can look at?
